Posts.Content: Thanks Chuck... i have read such wonderful, honest information here so far.. and I was just curious if this was an issue that was approached on a fairly common level with treatment... Life will change albeit slightly... hopefully, we'll remain more and more thankful every day for a good accurate diagnosis and a long healthy future.

Posts.Title: Depression issues

Posts.Content: Hello everyone. So glad we've found this community. Already the information has been very encouraging and helpful. My husband of 19 years (age 63) received this Dx earlier this month, and we are waiting surgery middle of December. I've read a tremendous amount regarding the logistics of surgery, etc, but I am curious as to any information regarding depression issues. This may seem trivial with life/death issues such as cancer, but I am very concerned with how my husband is going to handle this. We know there is nerve involvement on the right side of the prostate, so there will be no saving that nerve bundle, and I understand saving the nerve bundles are directly related to regaining sexual function. Did any of you go on depression meds to help you cope with these life changes? Should I mention my concerns to my husband's doctor? I really appreciate any and all information you can give me. Thank you in advance.
Posts.Signature: PSA 7/09 1.9, 9/10 2.3, 7/11 2.42, 8/12 3.44, 8/13 3.4, 9/14 4.9, 10/14 4.5 fPSA 9/14 9 Abnormal DRE 10/14 Biposy 10/29/14 16 core samples (8 on each side) 1/8 positive on left side Gleason 6 (3,3) <5% tissue involved 7/8 positive on right side - Gleason 7 (3,4) 40% tissue involvement, perineural invasion present Da Vinci surgery scheduled Dec 16, 2014 Catheter out at 2 weeks. Urine leakage still minor after two years No erections, even mild. Tried Cialis, Viagra and pumps. PSA 0.0 still after 2 years
Posts.Title: Depression issues

Posts.Content: Thanks guys.. I do truly appreciate the feedback.. and intend to let him know I will be there for him. I'm looking forward to a new life and new possibilties.. but I am definitely a glass half-full girl! In the meantime, the "reality" in me searches to learn all that I can... Thanks again.

Posts.Title: Depression issues

Posts.Content: Wondering if you all could provide some information on your physical symptoms prior to your DX, surgery, etc. My husband is very uncomfortable, having to sit "gingerly". The urologist explained that his prostate is 3 times the normal size, and in his words, "it's tight as a tick in there", and the doc is saying that he is hopeful that my husband will be one of those, who physically, feels MUCH better after surgery. He feels exhausted right now, and doesn't have much in the way of energy. We are hoping, once surgery is done, to see these areas of energy improve. But anyway, I was hoping some of you might share how you fared with your "other" physical symptoms, if you had any, other than the obvious regaining continence, sexual functions. Thanks in advance.

Posts.Title: Symptoms - Pre and Post-Surgery

Posts.Content: Lurover, I've ordered the book by Dr . Patrick Walsh as recommended by Highlander (the moderator). My husband and I were told by our urologist to get this also, because it is supposed to be a tremendous source of information... like Pratoman is saying... My husband's Gleason score is the same as yours 7 (3,4) which is a FAR better diagnosis than a Gleason 7 (4,3)... Hope you find the information you seek.

Posts.Title: So im ready for the surgery

Posts.Content: Pratoman, My husband still has varying degrees of soreness too, depending on the activities he does. His surgery was Dec 16, so I think you were a few weeks after him. Of course, he was having incredible soreness pre-surgery too, so we are hoping that when this is all healed, that he'll feel much better than pre-surgery. Definitely sounds normal to me... Thanks for your continuing posts.. It's helping me to keep him up to date too. Best wishes
